Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Minimalistic Estimators for Navigation of Miniature Mobile Platforms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
A new class of estimation methods are developed that can optimally utilize minima resources for high-precision pose tracking. This project develops the first formal methodologies for providing selections of parameters (e.g., camera frame rate, image resolution, number and type of detected features) for small portable devices to delay depletion of the battery. The approach is based on a rigorous study of the properties of the pose tracking problem with visual and inertial sensors and (1) identifies the fundamental limits of the attainable estimation accuracy, and (2) allows the analytical prediction of the accuracy as a function of the use of the sensing and processing resources. This makes possible the development of algorithms that optimally allocate system resources whose design relies on an optimization framework where the estimation errors constitute the cost function to be minimized, the resource limitations are explicitly modeled as constraints, and all the relevant design parameters (e.g., camera frame rate, number of features used) are the optimization variables. The immediate impact of this research effort is the increased cost efficiency and accuracy for navigation tasks in diverse applications.

The developed technology is available to the wider community through open-source position-tracking software for mobile phone devices and provides useful assistive technology. We engage K-12 students at local outreach events and introduce them to engineering as well collaborate with MESA, a long-standing program at the University of California at Riverside with a proven record of attracting underrepresented minority students to science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recent years, the availability of GPS positioning capabilities on a multitude of consumer devices has led to the development of a host of location-based applications, which have become an indispensable part of everyday life. However, GPS-based location estimates are limited to outdoor applications. Moreover, their accuracy is not sufficient for applications such virtual and augmented reality, which are bound to revolutionize the way in which humans interact with computers and the environment.

In this project, we have developed techniques that enable highly accurate estimation of the position and orientation of miniature systems without the requirement for GPS reception. The methods that were developed rely on the use of inexpensive cameras, gyroscopes and accelerometers, all of which are widely available in modern consumer electronics. In our work, we have focused on designing algorithms that process the data coming from these sensor using very limited amounts of CPU resources, thus allowing operation with commodity hardware, and prolonging the battery life of the devices. Among other results, this work has led to the first, to the best of our knowledge, live demonstration of high-precision indoor location estimation with a commercially available cellphone device.

The results of the work conducted as part of this project make it possible to develop a new generation of applications for consumer devices, which will use position and orientation estimates of unprecedented precision, in order to navigate and map indoor spaces, augment our perception of the environment with semantic information, and create new human-computer interfaces. In addition to the consumer applications, the results of our work can be employed for the creation of navigation aids for the visually impaired, as well as for enabling indoor operation for mobile robots and miniature autonomous flying vehicles.

The research findings that were made possible from this project were made public through a series of publications at international venues, live demonstrations of the developed indoor localization capabilities, and at outreach events in K-12 institutions in the wider Riverside, CA area.
